data.title: Carlisle Companies Inc reports results for the quarter ended December 31 - Earnings Summary
data.description:
• Carlisle Companies Inc reported quarterly adjusted earnings of $4.47​​ per share for the quarter ended December 31, higher than the same quarter last year, when the company reported EPS of $4.17. The mean expectation of eight analysts for the quarter was for earnings of $4.42 per share. Wall Street expected results to range from $4.31 to $4.54 per share.

  • Revenue fell 0.4% to $1.12 billion from a year ago; analysts expected $1.16 billion.

  • Carlisle Companies Inc's reported EPS for the quarter was $3.57​.

  • The company reported quarterly net income of $162.8 million.

  • Carlisle Companies Inc shares had risen by 3.4% this quarter.

FORECAST CHANGES

  • The mean earnings estimate of analysts had fallen by about 0.1% in the last three months.​

  • In the last 30 days, two analysts negatively revised earnings estimates

RECOMMENDATIONS

  • The current average analyst rating on the shares is "buy" and the breakdown of recommendations is 5 "strong buy" or "buy," 3 "hold" and no "sell" or "strong sell."

  • The average consensus recommendation for the construction supplies & fixtures peer group is also "buy"

Wall Street's median 12-month price target for Carlisle Companies Inc is $467.50

data.title: Yokohama Rubber Completes Acquisition of Goodyear's Off-the-Road Tire Business
data.description:
The Yokohama Rubber Co. finalized the acquisition of Goodyear's mining and construction machinery tire business, according to a Tuesday filing on the Tokyo Stock Exchange.

The Japanese tire maker said the move strengthens its off-highway tire segment under its medium-term growth plan, Yokohama Transformation 2026.

The company plans to consolidate the acquired business from the first quarter of 2025.

data.title: ASX Small-Cap Stocks to Watch
data.description:
Investors are likely to keep an eye on the following small-cap stocks listed on the Australian Securities Exchange.

Golden State Mining

Golden State Mining submitted heritage survey requests for the Yule and Southern Cross East projects in Western Australia, while a geochemical results review is underway to assess the drilling potential at the Canning Hill project.

Westar Resources

Westar Resources received heritage approvals for proposed reverse circulation drilling at the Mindoolah Gold Mining Center, within the Mindoolah gold project in Western Australia. The program is expected to start in mid-February.

FMR Resources

FMR Resources said the refinement of very low frequency-electromagnetic targets and 3D inversion modeling confirmed conductive trends, enhancing planned drill targets at its Fairfield copper project in Canada.

Magnum Mining and Exploration

Magnum Mining and Exploration lodged a prospectus with the Australian Securities and Investments Commission regarding a pro-rata entitlement offer of two new shares for every five shares held on Feb. 10, along with one free attaching option for every share applied for. The entitlement offer will raise up to AU$1.9 million by issuing up to 323.7 million shares at AU$0.006 apiece and 323.7 million options exercisable at AU$0.012 within three years.

Sipa Resources

Sipa Resources is acquiring four new gold projects, three in South Australia and one in Western Australia, with plans for exploration underway. The initial focus is on gold-in-calcrete sampling on the Tunkillia North project in South Australia.

data.title: South Korea January Inflation Accelerates Faster Than Expected — Update
data.description:
By Kwanwoo Jun

South Korea's headline inflation accelerated at a faster-than-expected pace in the first month of the year to stay above the central bank's 2% target.

The benchmark consumer-price index rose 2.2% in January from a year earlier, following a 1.9% gain in December, on higher prices for groceries and energy products, the country's statistics office said Wednesday.

The latest print, the highest since July, beat the median forecast from 11 economists in a Wall Street Journal poll tipping a 2.0% gain for January.

The pickup in price growth was largely led by Lunar New Year holiday-driven demand for agricultural and fishery products as well as higher gasoline and diesel prices, according to analysts.

Compared with the prior month, the index gained 0.7% in January, also beating the median forecast in the WSJ poll for a 0.5% increase. In December, consumer prices rose 0.4% from the previous month.

Core CPI, which strips out volatile food and energy prices, rose 1.9% from a year earlier in January and gained 0.5% from the previous month.

South Korea's largely subdued inflation, alongside weakening exports growth, has opened up room for the central bank to ease monetary policy settings further.

Both the Bank of Korea and the government forecast that inflation will trend lower in 2025 after years of efforts to curb price pressures. Inflation averaged 2.3% in 2024.

The BOK, which in November forecast that inflation would cool to 1.9% this year, is set to revise its outlook later in February, amid growing downside risks.

The finance ministry in January projected that inflation will average 1.8% in 2025, down from its earlier forecast of 2.1%.

The BOK in January kept its policy rate unchanged after back-to-back rate cuts in October and November but signaled that more easing is coming down the road.

Write to Kwanwoo Jun at kwanwoo.jun@wsj.com

data.title: Westpac Banking Confirms Investment in Lawpath to Grow Small Business Lending
data.description:
Westpac Banking confirmed its investment and partnership with legal services provider Lawpath to support startups and small-to-medium-sized businesses, the company said in a statement on Wednesday.

An Australian Financial Review report earlier today said the investment is AU$10 million.

Lawpath is an online platform that provides businesses access to affordable legal, accounting, and compliance technology services, the filing said.

data.title: Singapore's Keppel annual profit rises 5%
data.description:
Singapore's Keppel Ltd posted a 5% rise in its full-year underlying profit on Wednesday, helped by strong performance across it segments.

The asset manager's net profit from continuing operations for the 12 months ended Dec. 31 rose to S$1.06 billion ($784.20 million), from S$1.02 billion recorded a year earlier.

($1 = 1.3517 Singapore dollars)

data.title: Simon Property beats estimates for quarterly funds from operations
data.description:
Commercial real estate investment trust Simon Property Group beat market expectations for fourth-quarter funds from operations on Tuesday, as leasing demand remained steady for its U.S. malls and premium outlets.

The company saw revenue growth across its businesses while maintaining cost discipline, and said it plans to open premium outlets in Jakarta, Indonesia in March.

Simon Property expects 2025 net income in a range of $6.95 to $7.20 per share, above analysts' average estimate of $6.58, according to data compiled by LSEG.

The company saw occupancy rise to 96.5% as of Dec. 31, compared with 95.8% last year. Base minimum rent per square foot was $58.26, a 2.5% increase.

It reported FFO, a key measure of performance of a REIT, of $3.68 per share for the quarter, above $3.41 per share that analysts had estimated.

Quarterly revenue from lease income came in at $1.43 billion, compared with $1.40 billion analysts had estimated.

Shares of the company were largely unchanged in trading after the bell. Its stock rose 21% in 2024.

data.title: Nufarm's Earnings at Risk From U.S.-China Tariff Blows — Market Talk
data.description: Crop chemicals producer Nufarm's earnings likely aren't immune from tit-for-tat trade measures taken by the U.S. and China, contends Macquarie. The U.S. has imposed an additional 10% tariff on Chinese imports, prompting Beijing to respond. Macquarie highlights that 28% of Nufarm's earnings are from North America, and the company relies heavily on sourcing agricultural chemicals from China to sell into markets including the U.S. Nufarm's costs are likely to rise as the trade war unfolds. Still, Nufarm has some production in the U.S. and recently upgraded its manufacturing capacity in Australia so has "some ability to self-source," says Macquarie. It retains a neutral call on Nufarm. (david.winning@wsj.com; @dwinningWSJ)

data.title: Finning Sees Growth in Chile, Mixed Results in Canada — Commodity Comment
data.description:
By Stephen Nakrosis

Finning International, the world's largest Caterpillar dealer, said growing demand for copper is underpinning its outlook for Chile, while its outlook for Western Canada is mixed.

On the South America outlook:

Finning said in Chile it is seeing "growing global demand for copper, strong copper prices, capital deployment into large-scale brownfield expansions, and customer confidence to invest in brownfield and greenfield projects." It added it is also seeing "a broad-based level of quoting, tender, and award activity for mining equipment, product support, and technology solutions."

While activity levels and outlook remain positive, Finning said it is expecting a more challenging environment when attracting and retaining qualified labor.

The company also said it expects demand from large contractors supporting mining operations, with infrastructure construction activity remaining steady.

Finning said it continues to take a low-risk approach in Argentina. However, at the same time, it is positioning itself to capture opportunities, particularly in the oil and gas and mining sectors, it said. "The operating environment remains dynamic, and we continue to closely monitor the government's new rules and policies, some of which are helping drive large-scale investment."

On the Western Canada outlook:

Finning said it has a mixed outlook for Western Canada, as it expects large customers to continue practicing spending discipline as they work to achieve operating cost targets. However, these customers are expected to renew, maintain, and rebuild aging fleets going forward, the company said.

While ongoing commitments from federal and provincial governments and private sector projects will support activity in the construction sector, it is expected these projects will take time to advance, Finning said.

The company also said it sees opportunities for its power systems business in the face of growing demand for reliable, efficient and sustainable electric power solutions across communities in Western Canada.

On UK and Ireland operations:

Demand in the U.K. construction sector is expected to remain soft, Finning said.

"In power systems, quoting activity remains strong, driven by healthy demand for primary and backup power generation, particularly in the data center market," the company added.

Write to Stephen Nakrosis at stephen.nakrosis@wsj.com

data.title: Petroff Amshen LLP Urges New Yorkers to Review Credit Reports for Hidden Errors
data.description:
Inaccurate credit reports can lead to denied loans, higher interest rates, and lost job opportunities. Petroff Amshen LLP highlights the importance of proactive credit monitoring and offers legal assistance to correct discrepancies, empowering consumers to protect their financial future.

NEW YORK CITY, NEW YORK / ACCESS Newswire / February 4, 2025 / Petroff Amshen LLP is shedding light on the complexities of credit reports and the impact they have on financial stability and opportunity. In today's financial landscape, credit reports influence everything from loan approvals to employment decisions. Yet, many consumers remain unaware of the hidden inaccuracies that can undermine their financial standing. Petroff Amshen LLP emphasizes the importance of understanding and maintaining accurate credit reports to safeguard against unexpected setbacks.

A credit report is more than just a collection of numbers; it serves as a detailed record of an individual's financial history. Compiled by major credit reporting agencies like Equifax, Experian, and TransUnion, these reports contain personal information, credit accounts, public records, and a list of entities that have accessed the report. Lenders, employers, and landlords rely on this information to assess creditworthiness and reliability. Despite their significance, credit reports are not immune to errors, and even small discrepancies have major financial repercussions.

Petroff Amshen LLP frequently encounters cases where clients face hurdles due to errors on their credit reports. Unrecognized charges, outdated information, and duplicate entries are some of the most common issues consumers face. Fraudulent activity or clerical errors can result in debts being falsely attributed to individuals. Outdated debts that should no longer appear on credit reports can negatively impact credit scores, while duplicate entries can inflate the amount owed, prejudicing lenders' perceptions.

The firm urges consumers to be proactive in reviewing their credit reports. By law, New York residents are entitled to a free credit report once a year from each of the three major credit reporting agencies. Petroff Amshen LLP advises individuals to take advantage of this opportunity and thoroughly review all three major reports for any inconsistencies. Documenting any discrepancies and maintaining records of disputed charges is crucial. Submitting disputes directly to the credit reporting agencies with clear evidence ensures a stronger case for correction.

Taking swift action is essential, but resolving credit report errors is not always straightforward. Some issues require persistent follow-ups to ensure corrections are made within the legally mandated timeframe. When disputes become complex or errors persist despite multiple attempts, seeking legal assistance can be the most effective course of action. Petroff Amshen LLP offers dedicated services to navigate these challenges, leveraging federal and state laws to hold credit bureaus accountable. The firm meticulously reviews each case, identifying errors and managing all communication with credit bureaus and creditors, ultimately alleviating the burden on clients.

Beyond resolving errors, Petroff Amshen LLP believes in educating their clients so they can understand how credit reports function and the rights afforded to them under the law. This allows consumers to better protect themselves from future issues. This proactive approach not only addresses immediate concerns but also fosters long-term financial stability.

Accurate credit reports are essential for accessing financial opportunities, securing housing, and advancing careers. Petroff Amshen LLP is committed to ensuring that consumers' credit histories reflect their true financial position. By advocating for consumer rights and providing professional legal assistance, the firm plays a critical role in helping individuals regain control of their financial futures. For those facing credit report discrepancies or seeking guidance, Petroff Amshen LLP offers the knowledge and legal support necessary to navigate these challenges.

Contact Information

Gabriel Botero

Media Relations

media@petroffamshen.com

(718) 336-4200

SOURCE: Petroff Amshen LLP

View the original press release on ACCESS Newswire

data.title: Four Australian Property Owners That Could Beat Market Expectations — Market Talk
data.description: As reporting season gets underway, Citi identifies Australian real-estate investment trusts that could positively surprise with their results. It thinks Ingenia Communities's earnings guidance could beat consensus hopes on stronger sales. Analyst Howard Penny tips Goodman to update its data center pipeline, driving growth expectations. "Stronger than consensus expected sales growth, and positive spreads could support growth" for mall owner Scentre, Citi says. And turning to GPT, Citi expects its annual result to start "setting a foundation for medium-term growth off a reasonable value." (david.winning@wsj.com; @dwinningWSJ)

data.title: Insignia Financial Receives Takeover Bid From Brookfield Capital Partners
data.description:
Insignia Financial received a confidential, non-binding, and indicative takeover proposal via a scheme of arrangement from Brookfield Capital Partners at AU$4.60 cash per share, according to a Wednesday filing with the Australian bourse.

Brookfield's offer is the same as that of CC Capital Partners' revised proposal and Bain Capital's second revised proposal, the filing said.

To determine if Brookfield Capital can further sweeten its proposal, the wealth manager has granted the investment firm due diligence on a non-exclusive basis, the filing added.

The company confirmed there is no certainty of a transaction, and shareholders are advised no action is needed at this stage.

Insignia Financial appointed Citigroup and Gresham Advisory Partners as its financial advisers and King & Wood Mallesons as its legal adviser.

data.title: Brookfield triggers three-way bidding war for Insignia with $1.92 bln offer
data.description:
Australia's Insignia Financial said on Wednesday it had received an A$3.07 billion ($1.92 billion) takeover bid from Canadian firm Brookfield , matching the latest offers from Bain Capital and CC Capital Partners for the wealth manager.

Brookfield, in its proposal, has offered to buy the company at A$4.60 per share, representing a 6.5% premium to Insignia Financial's last closing price on Tuesday.

The Brookfield offer has triggered a three-way bidding war for Insignia, with U.S.-based Bain Capital and CC Capital Partners having already raised their respective bids for the company to $1.92 billion last month.

The bids come amid efforts by these companies to tap into Australia's lucrative A$4.1 trillion superannuation system.

Insignia has granted Brookfield limited due diligence to determine if an improved offer can be formulated, the company said in a statement.

($1 = 1.5995 Australian dollars)

data.title: Powell Industries Raises Quarterly Dividend
data.description:
By Stephen Nakrosis

Powell Industries said its board approved an increase to the company's quarterly cash dividend, raising it to 26.75 cents per share from 26.5 cents.

The new dividend will be payable on March 19 to shareholders of record at the close of business on Feb. 19. The dividend pays $1.07 annually.

Based on Tuesday's closing price of $233.14 for Powell shares, the new dividend represents a yield of about 0.4%.

The company last raised its dividend in January 2024.

Powell Industries provides custom engineered solutions for the management, control and distribution of electrical energy.

Write to Stephen Nakrosis at stephen.nakrosis@wsj.com

data.title: Enphase forecasts first-quarter revenue above expectations, shares rise
data.description:
Solar inverter maker Enphase Energy forecast first-quarter revenue above Wall Street expectations on Tuesday, after robust demand helped it post a better-than-expected fourth-quarter operating profit, sending its shares up about 6% after the bell.

The solar energy company forecast first-quarter revenue to be in the range of $340 million to $380 million, compared to analysts' expectations of $338.5 million, according to data compiled by LSEG.

The company said the forecast included shipments of 150 to 170 megawatt hours of IQ Batteries, which are used to store excess solar energy for later use, as well as about $50 million of safe harbor revenue, which is any sales made to customers who plan to install the inventory over more than one year.

"Stock up in after-market, but this (inclusion of 'safe harbor' revenue in Q1 guide) may be frowned upon as the Street fully digests it," GLJ Research LLC analyst Gordon L. Johnson said in a note.

In the U.S., Enphase's biggest market, revenue rose 6% sequentially due to higher microinverter sales in the quarter.

The Fremont, California-based company's adjusted net operating income came in at $120.4 million for the quarter ending Dec. 31, ahead of analysts' average estimate of $100.4 million, according to data compiled by LSEG.

data.title: South Korea consumer inflation accelerates to 6-month high
data.description:
South Korea's consumer inflation quickened to a six-month high in January, government data showed on Wednesday, coming in higher than market expectations on pressure from a weak local currency.

The consumer price index (CPI) rose 2.2% from a year earlier, after climbing 1.9% in the previous month, according to Statistics Korea. That compared with a median 1.97% increase forecast in a Reuters poll.

Inflation accelerated for the fourth straight month and marked the fastest since July 2024. It was also higher than the central bank's medium-term target of 2%.

Last month, the Bank of Korea unexpectedly kept its policy interest rate unchanged, after two straight meetings of rate cuts, signalling that it needed to wait for the domestic political turmoil weighing on the currency to stabilise before it could make further cuts.

Amid a weak local currency, South Korea's import prices, which affect consumer prices with a time lag of one or two months, rose in December at the fastest pace in five months.

In January, the won strengthened 1.3% against the dollar, after three straight months of falling. In 2024, the currency was the worst performer in Asia, weakening more than 12% and posting its biggest drop in 16 years.

On a monthly basis, the CPI rose 0.7%, also faster than the previous month's 0.4% gain and the fastest since August 2023.

Over the month, prices of petroleum products rose 3.5%, leading the gains on the index.

data.title: SKY Perfect JSAT Partners ArkEdge Space for Microsatellite Expansion
data.description:
SKY Perfect JSAT Holdings said its satellite business unit has entered into a capital and business partnership with ArkEdge Space to advance microsatellite missions, according to a Tuesday filing on the Tokyo Stock Exchange.

The collaboration aims to enhance SKY Perfect JSAT's satellite control and ground station services while supporting ArkEdge Space's development of microsatellite constellations.

Japan's largest satellite operator has allocated up to 10 billion yen for investments in space-related startups and ventures through 2030.

data.title: China's Retaliatory Tariffs Won't Move Coal Prices Much — Market Talk
data.description: Are China's 15% tariffs on U.S. coal meaningful for coal markets? That's the question posed by Morgan Stanley, which concludes any impact would be mostly be felt in metallurgical coal prices. Commodities strategist Helen Amos says China accounts for a relatively small share of U.S. coal exports. Still, U.S. exports of thermal and metallurgical coal to China increased over 2024. Morgan Stanley estimates tariffs would raise costs for around 3.4 million tons of thermal coal, representing less than 1% of traded volumes, and around 10.7 million tons of metallurgical coal, or some 3% of traded volumes. "We see negligible or only modest potential price impact of China's coal import tariffs, given both coal markets are currently well supplied," Morgan Stanley says. "But we watch for more meaningful shifts in met coal trade flows." (david.winning@wsj.com; @dwinningWSJ)

data.title: Chipotle falls after annual sales forecast comes in below expectations
data.description:
** Shares of Chipotle Mexican Grill down 5.1% at $55.98 in after-market trading

** Co forecast tepid annual comparable sales growth, expecting demand to be hurt by price hikes due to higher input costs, including that of beef and avocado, the latter facing further threat from President Trump's proposed tariffs

** Sees annual comparable sales growing low to mid-single digits, below analysts' expectations of a 5.6% growth, per data compiled by LSEG

** For Q4, co's comparable sales grew 5.4%, below estimates of a 5.6% growth, while adjusted EPS of 25 cents beat estimates of 24 cents

** CMG rose ~32% in 2024

data.title: Enphase Energy Shares Rise After 4Q Results, 1Q Outlook Beat Estimates
data.description:
By Sabela Ojea

Shares of Enphase Energy climbed after the company posted higher-than-expected revenue and adjusted earnings in the fourth quarter and its outlook for the first quarter beat estimates.

The stock was up 6.4%, to $70.48, in post-market trading Tuesday, representing the largest percent increase since December 2024. Through the close, shares have dropped 34% over the past 12 months.

The solar-energy company posted a fourth-quarter net profit of $62.2 million, or 45 cents a share, compared with $45.8 million, or 33 cents a share, for the same period a year earlier.

Stripping out one-time items, the company's earnings per share came in at 94 cents. Analysts polled by FactSet had forecast adjusted earnings of 73 cents a share.

Revenue rose 0.5%, to $382.7 million, beating the $377.2 million expected by Wall Street, according to FactSet.

"We are generally seeing stable demand in the U.S., both in California as well as outside of California," Chief Executive Badrinarayanan Kothandaraman said on a call with analysts. Outside the U.S., the company saw fourth-quarter revenue in Europe down 25% when compared to the third quarter.

For the first quarter, Enphase Energy guided for revenue of $340 million to $380 million, coming ahead of the $337.6 million forecast by analysts polled by FactSet.

Enphase believes its new products will help drive gradual revenue growth throughout 2025, with safe harbor ordering in the U.S. having the potential to accelerate growth as it progresses into the second half of 2025, Kothandaraman said, adding that overall the company has doubled down on U.S. manufacturing for microinverters and batteries.
